CreditLine: Acquired by William T. Walters, before 1889
Description: In this amusing scene, the tiger rolls on the ground, rubbing its back in a manner similar to that of domestic cats. The old oak tree resembles those that Barye sketched in the Forest of Fontainebleau. Barye repeated this tiger several times in his watercolors, altering the backgrounds.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: Untamed: The Art of Antoine-Louis Barye
Exhibitions.Textblock: Untamed: The Art of Antoine-Louis Barye. The Walters Art Museum, Baltimore; Philbrook Museum of Art, Tulsa; The Henry Morrison Flagler Museum, Palm Beach. 2007-2008.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: The Essence of Line: French Drawings from Ingres to Degas
Exhibitions.Textblock: The Essence of Line: French Drawings from Ingres to Degas. The Walters Art Museum, Baltimore; Baltimore Museum of Art, Baltimore; Birmingham Museum of Art, Birmingham; Tacoma Art Museum, Tacoma. 2005-2006.
The Works of Antoine-Louis Barye. American Art Gallery (New York), New York. 1889-1890.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: The Wild Kingdom of Antoine-Louis Barye, 1795-1875
Exhibitions.Textblock: The Wild Kingdom of Antoine-Louis Barye, 1795-1875. Wildenstein & Company, New York. 1994.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: The Road to Impressionism: Landscapes from Corot to Manet
Exhibitions.Textblock: The Road to Impressionism: Landscapes from Corot to Manet. The Walters Art Museum, Baltimore. 2004-2005.

Inscriptions: [Signature] Painted in lower right in red watercolor: BARYE;  [Transcription] Inscribed in graphite in center on verso: o bis
Medium: watercolor on moderately textured, moderately thick, cream wove paper
Provenance: Carmentier;  William T. Walters, Baltimore, prior to 1889, by purchase [George A. Lucas as agent];  Henry Walters, Baltimore, 1894, by inheritance;  Walters Art Museum, 1931, by bequest.
Title: Tiger Rolling
